name: building operation, luxury hotel | building operation, luxury hotel | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/21446/documentation

This dataset represents the operation of a tourist accommodation facility located in Lima, Peru. The case study hotel is classed as a luxury hotel (comfort category 5*). It was opened in 2012 as a brand new, stand-alone tourist accommodation facility. The hotel has capacity of 207 rooms (423 beds in total) and offers rooms of the following types (total number of rooms is given in brackets): double/twin (190), junior suite (7), executive suite (9), presidential suite (1). The hotel has 17 floors (13 above the ground and 4 under the ground) which host a lobby, a restaurant, a bar, a spa and event/conference rooms. Laundry is available on site. Parking lot is available on site. The hotel occupies a plot of 2570 m2 while the gross floor area (GFA) of the hotel is 20260 m2. The average annual occupancy of the hotel is 70% which is equal to 108077 guest nights per year . The case study hotel's occupancy is in line with the country's average of 66%; (Source: Hotel News Now 2015. The state of Peru's tourism, hotels. Available from: http://www.hotelnewsnow.biz/Articles/27650/The-state-of-Perus-tourism-hotels Accessed 16 March 2018).

This dataset is modelled to represent the service of operating a hotel. It includes: energy and water consumption, furniture and in-room textiles (such as bed linen, bed mattrasses and curtains), electric and electronic equipment used in guest rooms and on hotel premises (including bulbs), cleaning and in-room consumables. The case study hotel has laundry on-site and this activity is included. Although the case study hotel has a restaurant on site, the inputs of food items have been excluded due to data availability. The energy and water consumption attibuted to restaurant operations have been included. Any waste generated in restaurant operations has been included. Activities include hotel operations and infrastructure based on 1 guest night stay and the lifeframe of the hotel building of 75 years. 


Activities end with guest departure from hotel premises. Due to data availability, the following processes have been excluded: room equipment (on-table lamp, door lock, iron), bathroom equipment (showers, mirrors) and consumables (shower cap), kitchen equipment (mixer, deep fryer, ice-maker, heater, toaster), security equipment (security camera), food inputs in restaurant operations.
category: I:Accommodation and food service activities/55:Accommodation/551:Short term accommodation activities/5510:Short term accommodation activities

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The hotel is based in Lima, Peru.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Technology in use is considered current.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: In terms of operations, energy and water consumption are aggregate and represent the case study hotel as a whole, rather than its specific operational areas (e.g. guest rooms, restaurant and bar, kitchen, spa, laundry). The comments to respective processes explain this in detail.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Primary data from the hotel supplemented with literature-based calculations and estimates, where appropriate.

exchanges.description: This reference product represents operation of a tourist accommodation facility classed as a luxury hotel (comfort category 5*).

flow.name: building operation, luxury hotel
flow.category: I:Accommodation and food service activities/55:Accommodation/551:Short term accommodation activities/5510:Short term accommodation activities

exchanges.description: Calculated value from the total number of linen units used by the hotel. The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hotel/lifetime of the product) / (lifetime capacity). It is assumed that, on average, 4 linen units make 1 kg in weight. Source: Filimonau et al. 2011. Reviewing the carbon footprint analysis of hotels: Life Cycle Energy Analysis (LCEA) as a holistic method for carbon impact appraisal of tourist accommodation. Journal of Cleaner Production, 19, 1917-1930. Assumed average service life is 1 year (primary data from the hotel survey). The amount accounts for 10% fabric loss in the cotton textile manufacturing process. Source: Baydar, G., Ciliz, N., and Mammadov, A., 2015. Life cycle assessment of cotton textile products in Turkey. Journal of Cleaner Production, 104(A), 213-223.

exchanges.description:
Calculated value. The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hotel) / (lifetime capacity). Combined of all instances of use across the hotel operations. Represents the following cleaning luquids: glass/window cleaner, floor cleaner, bathroom cleaner, bleach, washing up liquid, carpet cleaner, odour eliminator. In terms of outputs assumed to have gone to wastewater. As the product "cleaning consumables" is expressed as 100% active substance, the amount of cleaning consumables is multiplied by the average concentration of active substance. According to Golsteijn (2015) the average water content of cleaning consumables is 86.4%, the necessary water input is accounted for with the flow "water, compeltely softened, from decarbonised water, at user". For more information on how the cleaning consumables dataset was created please refer to the relevant dataset in ecoinvent.

2015, Laura Golsteijn, A compilation of life cycle studies for six household detergent product categories in Europe: the basis for product-specific A.I.S.E. Charter Advanced Sustainability Profiles

exchanges.description: Estimated value. No data on the number of vacuum cleaners in use was provided by the case study hotel. Hence, data from the upmarket hotel, Peru, was used as proxy. According to the upmarket hotel, Peru, 1 vacuum cleaner is required to clean 2 hotel floors. Given the case study hotel has 17 floors, the nuber of vacuum cleaners in use was estimated as 17/2=8.5, rounded to 8 vacuum cleaners. The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hotel/lifetime of the product) / (lifetime capacity). Assumed average service life of a vacuum cleaner is 8 years. Source: Gallego-Schmid et al. 2016. Life cycle environmental impacts of vacuum cleaners and the effects of European regulation. Science of the Total Environment, 559, 192-203.

exchanges.description: Estimated value. The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hotel/lifetime of the product) / (lifetime capacity). Assumed average service life of all pieces of furniture is 15 years. This represents service life of an average piece of furniture. Source: European Commission 2013. BACKGROUND REPORT. Revision of Ecolabel and Green Public Procurement criteria for the product group Wooden Furniture. September 2013. Available from: http://susproc.jrc.ec.europa.eu/furniture/docs/Background_report_Furniture_September_2013.pdf Accessed 19 March 2018. This exchange represents the following: Bed king/queen (unit) King bed is assumed to have a weight of 30 kg, no headboard, Furniture re-use Network, 2009. Average weights. Available from: http://democracy.york.gov.uk/documents/s2116/Annex%20C%20REcycling%20Report%20frnweights2005.pdf Accessed 13 January 2018. Sofas (unit) Sofa is assumed to have a weight of 37 kg, two seater, Furniture re-use Network, 2009. Average weights. Available from: http://democracy.york.gov.uk/documents/s2116/Annex%20C%20REcycling%20Report%20frnweights2005.pdf Accessed 13 January 2018. Tables/Desks (unit) Table is assumed to have a weight of 23 kg, medium, Furniture re-use Network, 2009. Average weights. Available from: http://democracy.york.gov.uk/documents/s2116/Annex%20C%20REcycling%20Report%20frnweights2005.pdf Accessed 13 January 2018. Chairs (unit) Chair is assumed to have a weight of 7 kg, Furniture re-use Network, 2009. Average weights. Available from: http://democracy.york.gov.uk/documents/s2116/Annex%20C%20REcycling%20Report%20frnweights2005.pdf Accessed 13 January 2018. Wardrobe (unit). Wardrobe is assumed to have a weight of 55 kg (double wardrobe), Furniture re-use Network, 2009. Average weights. Available from: http://democracy.york.gov.uk/documents/s2116/Annex%20C%20REcycling%20Report%20frnweights2005.pdf Accessed 13 January 2018. Shelves (unit). Shelf is assumed to have a weight of 35 kg, Furniture re-use Network, 2009. Average weights. Available from: http://democracy.york.gov.uk/documents/s2116/Annex%20C%20REcycling%20Report%20frnweights2005.pdf Accessed 13 January 2018.

exchanges.description: Data from the hotel survey. The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hotel) / (lifetime capacity). The amount also includes electricity requirements to produce cotton textile products from raw cotton. It is estimated that 2 MJ of electricity is required to produce 1 kg of cotton textile product. This accounts for 10% fabric loss in the cotton textile manufacturing process. Source: Baydar, G., Ciliz, N., and Mammadov, A., 2015. Life cycle assessment of cotton textile products in Turkey. Journal of Cleaner Production, 104(A), 213-223.

exchanges.description:
Calculated value. From the dataset for "cleaning consumables production" GLO 2011-2013, on average cleaning products contain 86% of water. Based on the literature source Golsteijn (2015) the dataset used to represent the water flow is "water, completely softened, at plant", version 2 dataset which corresponds to ecoinvent version 3 dataset "water, completely softened, from decarbonised waterm at user". The amount of water needed is therefore calculated based on the vale of 86% calculated based on Golsteijn (2015) and the amount of cleaning consumable which are expressed as 100% active substance.

Laura Golsteijn, 2015, A compilation of life cycle studies for six household detergent product categories in Europe: the basis for product-specific A.I.S.E. Charter Advanced Sustainability Profiles

Revision of Ecolabel and Green Public Procurement criteria for the product group Wooden Furniture. September 2013. Available from: http://susproc.jrc.ec.europa.eu/furniture/docs/Background_report_Furniture_September_2013.pdf Accessed 19 March 2018. In terms of outputs assumed to have gone to scrap steel.

exchanges.description: Calculated value. Represents here curtains and carpets made of nylon. The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hotel/lifetime of the product) / (lifetime capacity). An everage curtain is assumed to have a weight of 5 kg. Source: Furniture re-use Network, 2009. Average weights. Available from: http://democracy.york.gov.uk/documents/s2116/Annex%20C%20REcycling%20Report%20frnweights2005.pdf Accessed 13 January 2018. An everage carpet is assumed to have a weight of 25 kg. Source: Furniture re-use Network, 2009. Average weights. Available from: http://democracy.york.gov.uk/documents/s2116/Annex%20C%20REcycling%20Report%20frnweights2005.pdf Accessed 13 January 2018.Average service life of a curtain is assumed to be equal to average service life of a carpet which is 10 years. Source: Greenspec 2018. Whole life costing: carpets. Available from: http://www.greenspec.co.uk/building-design/carpets/ Accessed 16 March 2018. In terms of outputs assumed to have gone to waste polyethylene.

Assumed average service life of a hair dryer is 3 years. Source: Ashby 2009. Materials and the Environment: Eco-Informed Material Choice. Elsevier, Burlington, USA

exchanges.description: Estimated value. Represents here laundry detergent. As no primary data on the amount of laundry detergent used by the case study hotel was provided, the primary data on laundry detergent use from upmarket hotel, Peru, was used as proxy accounting for the difference in hotel occupancy. Lifetime production volume of the upmarket hotel, Peru, is 5625000 guest nights. Lifetime production volume of the case study hotel is 8105775 guest nights and the amount of laundry detergent in use is 125 kg. The amount of laundry detergent used by the case study hotel was therefore calculated as 125*(8105775/5625000) = 180.13 The amount of exchange is then calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hotel) / (lifetime capacity). In terms of outputs assumed to have gone to wastewater.
